title: HSBC Joins Ranks of European Stock Bulls
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Thu, Jul 23, 2015, 12:54 BST - UK Markets close in 3 hrs 36 mins HSBC Joins Ranks of European Stock Bulls The Wall Street Journal – 14 minutes ago After weeks of nervously watching the latest developments in Greece’s debt crisis, European equity investors have a new focus: corporate profits. 
Europe’s second-quarter earnings season has only just started, but the early signs are good. 
According to research published by HSBC Thursday, 55% of companies have so far beaten average analyst profit forecasts. That is above the long-term average which they say is 48%. 
It is early days—the data only account for 32 out of 270 companies— but the results “give grounds for optimism”, strategists at the bank write. 
Fund managers are taking notice. 
“We’ve seen almost no sign of earnings growth in Europe for more than five years. Now is the time that we need the earnings to come through – and they are starting to do just that,” said Michael Barakos, chief investment officer for European equities at J.P. Morgan Asset Management, which has around $1.8 trillion in assets under management. 
A weaker euro has been the main driver for the strong performance of European equities over the past quarter, HSBC says. 
A fall in the currency tends to boost demand for goods produced within the eurozone from buyers outside of the eurozone. Despite stabilizing in recent months, the euro remains close to 10% lower against the U.S. dollar so far this year. 
But it is not all about exchange rates. 
The HSBC strategists say that economic growth is returning to Europe, which is supporting production and demand. And HSBC isn’t alone in its optimism on European earnings and stock performance. 
Earlier this week, analysts at Goldman Sachs published a note in which they predicted the Stoxx Europe 600—the region’s benchmark index—will rise by 1.9% over the next three months. 
They wrote that over the last few weeks, the better growth picture in Europe had been overshadowed by risks relating to Greece. 
“With the new bailout deal being finalized, we think the focus will shift back to macro fundamentals, at least in the near-term,” the Goldman analysts wrote. 
Stocks in Europe earlier this week capped their longest winning streak since April 2014, largely fueled by Athens striking a deal with creditors to negotiate a new bailout. 
From its May high to its July low, the Stoxx Europe 600 slipped more than 9%. So far in July it is up close to 5% and it is within reaching distance of an all-time high hit in April this year. 
But some investors are growing cautious on European stock markets after the recent rally. 
Russell Investments marginally increased its exposure to European shares on July 14, after Greece clinched a deal to negotiate a fresh bailout with its international creditors. 
Investment strategists at the company have said that if the Stoxx Europe 600 hits an all-time high shares would look expensive and they would consider selling. More from The Wall Street Journal
